comments.commentBody:
Heh...reminds me of the old Army maxim "hurry up and wait"...oh if only soldiers could form unions....

A lot of the companies profiled in this article sound like they really could use a nice big wallop of regulation...on the other hand, I don't trust the unions to do anything but recreate the kind of nonsense we find in the government sector.

Anyone ever deal with the City College bureaucracy?? Really makes you wish Romney would swoop in and pink-slip some of these public sector bozos who take forever to send paperwork back and forth only to finally lose it completely -- I kid you not!
rexl: a very interesting comment, considering that it is Russia where all boundaries between government and secret services had been (by openly stated policy) erased.

John: sure. On one hand, a recording of the US official trying to figure out, in terms of US interests (her job!), what is going on in Ukraine. On the other hand, Russia sending GRU troops, mercenaries and weaponry (tanks!). Very good comparison.

"Who is dictating our foreign policy these days"

Great mystery of our times!

So, we do not punish our banks for ruining the global economy and almost bringing about the end of civilization, but we are going to punish the Russians for a situation in which it is impossible to separate the CIA, FBI, and various disparate entities with obfuscated interests and irons in the fire.
Who is dictating our foreign policy these days.

Plenty of us have been clients, Jack. You get what you pay for, and I take seriously that I have paid for someone's time, that I should not pull the rug out from them on short notice.  I suspect many businesses get the customers they deserve.

EU may not have an option but cooperate on sanctions. No one is going to allow 40 million refugees flooding Europe after the current hybrid war launched by Kremlin turns into a full scale invasion and inevitable compromise of numerous Ukrainian nuclear power plants. Never think twice, sanctions is the cheapest and long overdue remedy to avoid major disaster in Europe.

@Professor. "Chasing the Chimera of Hama militancy?" You are kidding, right?

Hamas wants to exterminate all Jews. Recently Hamas targeted Israel's nuclear power plant to try to cause a nuclear accident. What further proof do you need, Professor?

The UN requested cease-fire belated though yet welcome, still given the fear psychosis on both sides peace would always be elusive. As for the annexation plan of Gaza, what better situation the Hamas could visualize than taking the terror war into the Israeli mainland and keep the Israeli politico-military establishment perpetually engaged chasing the Chimera of Hama militancy?

So about 30 years ago A T & T was forced to break up because it had a monopoly on telephone service in the U. S. We were told this was better for consumers. Yet since that time we've come to have bigger banks, media companies, etc. How is this better for those of us who are consumers?

Murdoch and his associates already have too much influence . They don't need any more.

I loved College Joe's phrase "until people of my generation come to appreciate that the corporate state is even less receptive to our needs than the government".  That just resonated with me because I believe that was a wonderful way of succinctly encapsulating Americans' plight these days, and I am older than the millenial group...

I stopped reading Wall Street Journal when Murdoch took over (not that I liked it before that) And now he is coming after the ones I like and read/watch - TIME, HBO, TCM, TNT...

Is it reasonable to fear that I can only read/watch/listen to the likes of Hannity, O'Reilly, Coulter, Rush, Kelly, etc. in my current favorite media outlets, if and when Murdoch takes over Time Warner? Ugh!

Is it also likely that he might target New York Times? If that ever happens I am leaving the country! In that event, Honduras may be a safer place to move to!!!

Kevin McCarthy is in Congress because he is a Republican in one if the few areas of the state where voter registration runs in favor of Republicans. He is now in the process of changing his positions. Ex-Im Bank? He used to support it, but not now. Immigration reform so vital to California agriculture? Oh no, we just can't work on that. And the agri-business giants crying for more water (they already get 80 %!!!)? Those giants planted almond trees --- makes a lot of money, but they are a very, very thirsty tree. And, in a dry year, you either water them or they die. Maybe a smart farmer would know going in that if your water supply is not guaranteed and you can't fallow a field to save water, planting almonds is risky business. Oh, my bad, these folks are free market capitalists who know their money is at risk so they cut that risk by going to their friendly congressman to protect their bank account. Because that water is just their property, now and forever. And as for that bullet train, it was Central Valley politicians like McCarthy who demanded that the line go to smaller cities like Bakersfield and Fresno. Want a profitable and cheaper line? Run it from San Diego to LA and then to San Jose/San Francisco on one line and Sacramento on another - nonstop fromLA. Faster, cheaper, competitive with air travel, simpler, better. Thanks for reading -- sorry for venting but in California it is not common to get to take these shots at elected Republicans as they are endangered here.

Very enjoyable puzzle with a good AHA moment.

Here is fun version of "Walking in Memphis" ==>
http://tinyurl.com/oxtakbc

I shore hate the misuse of the word 'littoral'.

That article was confusing to read (both ways), but the clip was excellent. Deadline just linked it yesterday, but its worth hearing 2x.

Weird Al produces some extremely clever numbers: his palindrome song, "Bob", is an absolute jaw-dropper, and I just discovered this number, which I'm going to e-mail to everyone in my address book.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KCSA7kKNu2Y
Actually, this is a perfect example of inappropriate uses of "literally."
Thank you for that song!  Turns out it's captioned with the words coming across the screen in different type styles and was just perfect.

An excellent, and appropriate use of "literally." If you are as pi**ed off as I am about those who use "literally" when they mean "figuratively," there's an app for that!

http://www.mediaite.com/online/app-literally-removes-the-word-literally-...

There is also a song.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Gv0H-vPoDc

Mr. McClintock is my congressman; a more feckless, uninformed, and ineffective dolt has never entered the House of Representatives.  Unfortunately, the 4th District is very, very red, and someone of the same stripe will most likely be elected were he to be replaced.

Steve:  You, my neighbor, are correct.  And that is why I am leaving this beautiful (but racist) area for greener pastures.  McClintock's pronouncements are not only uninformed, but are blatant lies, something the GOP and its TV propaganda network are  superb at.  It looks to me as if McCarthy is of the same ilk, albeit perhaps a bit more sly and better rehearsed.

Tom McClintock about Kevin McCarthy: “He has a vivid understanding of California public policy."  What, in the name of God, is a "vivid understanding"?    For all their nativist fervor, the Republicans lack a single leader who can articulate a coherent thought in the English language.  Send 'em all back to...wherever it is that dimwits hail from.

As the article makes clear, Microsoft knew when it acquired the Nokia businesses that it would make cuts. In fact, that was probably a big part of the attraction of purchasing those businesses: promote synergy, allowing redundant staff to be eliminated, thus increasing efficiency. It's not folly at all; it's shrewd business.
Can't imagine why Nokia sold out to uSoft.  They signed their death warrant thereby.  Their future lay with Android or iOS and they didn't know it.  Too late.

Microsoft has lost its way. It was the premier desktop software company. But desktops are fading. Now it's what, Bing? Xbox? Skydrive? Surface? Nokia? Microsoft today is far from shrewd. It seems to be throwing any product it can think of against the wall, to see what sticks. The Nokia deal was a huge mistake. But those jobs would have been lost in any case, Nokia was spiraling toward bankruptcy when Ballmer came along...
An analysis of where the cuts fell will be helpful to ken future directions.  Nokia employees are expected to take the brunt, which admits the folly of that former acquisition.

Inflation is by definition a zero sum game: the sum of all that losers lose must exactly equal the sum of all the gains to gainers. Certainly hyperinflation is bad because it shifts productive work to speculation activities, but even that's the pot calling the kettle black, what with all the rigged hedge fund activity by Ivy grads on Wall St. By the way, the ones who scream they are on "fixed incomes" are the only ones not on fixed incomes -- seniors have their social security indexed to inflation. Why? Because they lobbied for it back in the 1970s. Yet good luck to workers ever getting a cost of living hike in minimum wage. Low inflation since 1983 hasn't done anything to prevent the decline in real wages nor halt the pocketing of productivity premiums by management and corporate owners.

I love the anecdote about the group asking the state government to send them the bill for the flu vaccines. No problem! They have plenty of federal money. We pay for everything no matter what the bill is.

This smacks of the 1% gaining too much control in the U.S. I doubt this is a good thing for freedom of speech and our democratic principles.  Many years ago "The Biggies" were rebuffed by the Fed for take over bids, if my recollection is correct.  A question that's begs an answer, is what will U.S. citizens and the nation gain if such a take over is permitted?

You make this appear as though any citizen, LEGAL citizen, wishes ill toward these children. I do not. These children are not to blame. They are PAWNS . Please do not play the religious card with us.. Pope Francis should be telling his "faithful" to STOP bringing children into an overpopulated world. I cannot get food stamps. Help ME
Sure,  because uniquely among nations Israel does not have the right to defend her people?  Hamas terrorists started this but Israel will finish it.

Joe Y

People on main street own stocks and work for the companies who sell shares on the stock exchange. These companies also do business with many smaller companies who employ people. A bursting of the stock market bubble would result in higher unemployment and investment loses for a lot of people.

The good news is that it would also lower prices, and the ending of QE would mean less accumulation of government debt. If the government cut spending and lowered taxes as well, this would free up money for investment purposes and business would eventually pick up again and people would be back to work, but with less taxes to pay and less debt. Mind you, the government would have to stop getting into debt and stop creating bubbles via the Fed, otherwise there would eventually be another bubble.
Smuggled, manipulated children are still children. And no one said being the good guys is easy.
If they were fleeing from Cuba they would have to run a gauntlet of government guns trying to keep them *in* Cuba.

400,000 were deported. This doesn't mean 400,000 "invaders" are entering the country.

Many are among the 11 million who have lived here for years, supporting their families, paying taxes, and contributing to their communities until one day they are stopped for a minor traffic violation and are caught up in the Secure Communities program and deported.

Stop these invaders at the border.  I have no sympathy when these foreign invaders are being treated better than many poor and minority children in this country.  Statistics show that 400+ thousand illegals are deported each year and the estimated number of illegals in the country is on the rise again (PEW). This means that at least 400+ thousand invaders are entering the country.  Obama says the border is secure.  400+ thousand illegal entries does not seem secure to me.  Pollsters never ask how many of those supporting immigration reform want the border secured first.  Must be they are afraid of the results.
Wrong.  Numerous UN resolutions have condemned Israel, but not in the Security Council.
Here, let me google that for you: http://lmgtfy.com/?q=what+happened+to+the+stars+hoop+dreams
Here's link to follow-up story from 2012 in the Wall Street Journal on the post-documentary lives of the HOOP DREAMS pair: http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2012/06/07/what-ever-happened-to-the-star...

I wonder how the 2 young men featured in the documentary, Hoop Dreams are doing. This story has echoes of that. We see and hear the hype about the minuscule few who make it to the tippy top.

I wish Mr. Taylor much success. Who knows maybe he will get his dream job.

this is a war greg. of course we need to minimize civilian deaths as much as possible. did you cry this much because of all the civilians we accidentally killed in iraq and afghanistan? the best solution is to get the civilians out of the war zone (i.e. gaza) until the fighting is over. the international community needs to find a place for them to go.
